posts.post_content: I dislike it on the grounds that, with Darksteel, you could at least hold it off. Get a Jareth, Leonine Titan out, and you can chump-block it till the cows come home. posts.post_content:
@ CrowJonSnow  
  
[Day of Judgment](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Day of Judgment), [Damnation](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Damnation), and [Wrath of God](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wrath of God) don't kill Blightsteel Colossus because he is indestructible.  
  
700.4. If a permanent is indestructible, rules and effects can't destroy it. (See rule 701.6, "Destroy.") Such permanents are not destroyed by lethal damage, and they ignore the lethal-damage state-based action (see rule 704.5g). Rules or effects may cause an indestructible permanent to be sacrificed, put into a graveyard, or exiled.  
  
[Gatekeeper of Malakir](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gatekeeper of Malakir) does force a sacrifice of Blightsteel, assuming he doesn't have another creature, which is unlikely since many decks like to [Shape Anew](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Shape Anew) with tokens.  
  
[Black Sun's Zenith](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Black Sun's Zenith) does place Blightsteel in the graveyard as a state based effect for having 0 toughness (704.5f If a creature has toughness 0 or less, it's put into its owner's graveyard. Regeneration can't replace this event. ). However, y... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Rules or effects may cause an indestructible permanent to be sacrificed, put into a graveyard, or exiled.
